results.title: Half life
results.brief_description: Filmed in an abandoned silo in Collingwood and featuring the haunting vocals of Wendy Rule, this music video examines a woman trapped by her own depression. Nominated for an ATOM Award.

results.title: Half a year apart
results.brief_description: Shows two young children six months apart in age playing, highlighting their needs, capabilities and styles of play. Rachel, the two year old, is caught up in the delight of sensory world; Josh at two and a half has developed an interest in what makes things work.

results.title: Half a sixpence
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Charles H. Schneer and George Sidney
results.brief_description: Based on the H.G. Wells novel ‘Kipps’, Tommy Steele stars as Arthur Kipp, a young draper’s assistant who inherits a fortune and enters Edwardian society. Arthur finds out that wealth doesn’t necessarily buy happiness. Apart from the lavish costumes, this production features some big numbers such as the title song and the wonderful “What a picture’. Also stars Julia Foster.

results.title: Half a pint of milk
results.creator_credit: Tasmania. Education Dept. and Malcolm Otton
results.brief_description: Made to show the work involved in producing the half a pint of milk issued each day to all Tasmanian school children under the free milk scheme. The film shows those parts of Tasmania most suited to dairy farming, the yearly round of work on a typical dairy farm, the breeding of dairy cattle and the pasteurisation and bottling of the finished product at the milk factory.

results.brief_description: A close-up view, of crew racing, from the place of the man at the oars. On the occasion of a North American rowing competition, this film follows a University of British Columbia team through practice, trials and competition

results.title: Hajj: the journey of a lifetime [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Ovidio Salazar
results.brief_description: Join a group of British Muslims including a father and his son, a university student and a Harley Street neurosurgeon (both women) as they make their spiritual journey of discovery on a pilgrimage to the 2001 hajj in Saudi Arabia, along with 20,000 other Britons. For Muslims everywhere, the ultimate goal is to make the hajj at least once during their lifetime. This spiritual journey is the basic premise of an entire religion and sees impoverished African Muslims mixing with their incredibly wealthy Western counterparts. The film covers the entire event from the preparations in England before flying off to Saudi Arabia, their arrival and bus trip to Mecca and the days that follow which take them to Mina and Mount Arafat where they undergo many rites and ceremonies before finally returning to Mecca and flying back home. Interspersed throughout the documentary we are given an insight into each of these traveller’s thoughts and aspirations, through their own personal commentary, of what hajj means to them, their expectations and their actual experiences and why they have embarked on such a pilgrimage. For the Saudis this annual event requires an enormous amount of preparation providing food, water, electricity and tent accommodation for over 2 million pilgrims for the 6 days of the hajj. There are some amazing images throughout the film particularly the circling of the Kabah, but the one overwhelming factor is the patience and good humor of the pilgrims and the spirituality which seems to embody them as a whole in their united belief in Islam. Narrated by Art Malik.

results.title: Hairy tales
results.brief_description:
“Hairy tales” is a group-devised story made by children about a group of children who get lost in the Australian bush and who are finally rescued by a magical emu that shows them the way home.
The work was commissioned and made by a group of children who attended a filmmaking and drama workshop over three weekends at the Artplay Centre in Melbourne - a new children’s contemporary art centre established by the City of Melbourne.
The children developed the narrative using theatrical improvisation techniques taught in the workshop. The visuals were created by compositing live action and animation using a “black screen” technique providing opportunities for either drawn or filmed backgrounds that were added in post-production. The children participating in the workshops created all the content for the film. The film was directed and edited by multimedia artist Michael Buckley and produced for Artplay by creative producer, Sue McCauley.

results.title: Hairspray
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Rachel Talalay and John Waters
results.brief_description: The frenzied, all-out dancing, all rockin’ rememberance of Baltimore 1962. A time infested with glamour crazed teens to whom TV was everything. Featuring an electric combination of talents that include Divine, Sonny Bono and Debbie Harry, set around Baltimore’s coolest pop show, “The Corny Collins Show”. Happy teen viewers thrill to watching their towns’ coolest teens rock to the country’s trendiest new dances. One such viewer is Tracy Turnblad, a tubby teenager who lives her dream by getting her big shot on the show. However, Tracy finds herself in bitter competition with the show’s reigning teen queen, bitchy Amber Von Tussle. They battle not only for the crown but also for the true love of teen hunk, Link.

results.title: Haircuts and Music: Robert Forster in conversation with Michael Dwyer
results.brief_description: Every change that David Bowie makes comes with a new haircut. The boy can’t help it. As the seventies was his greatest decade as a songwriter and musician, so we marvel at his hair at that time. From Bowie’s first steps into the music business in the mid-sixties, he was a keen student of rock history and the supreme importance of an artist’s image. Each of his hairstyles from that time on alerted the public to where he was musically. Robert Forster will guide us, and plot the Bowie seventies journey from the hippy locks of ‘The Man Who Sold The World’, to the famous Ziggy cut and album, to the coiffured soul-boy of ‘Young Americans’, through to the dramatic renunciation of image that Bowie’s return to his natural hair colour and style for the fabled ‘Berlin Trilogy’ of albums represented.

results.title: Hair
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Lester Persky, Michael Butler and Milos Forman
results.brief_description: Despite the sceptics, Milos Forman transformed the ultimate “tribal rock musical” of the 1960’s into an exuberant film experience. The score is performed in a variety of locations including table tops, Central Park, Wall Street and in march formation aboard a plane heading for Vietnam. “Hair” is not just a nostalgic look at the ‘60’s and “The Age of Aquarius”, but the ideals it espouses about peace, individual freedom, joy and love are just as passionate and relevant today, as they were shocking and radical at the time of America’s involvement in Vietnam. Gerome Ragni and James Rado worked on this film production of their original stageplay.
